 I.

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on (i) a proposed
loan  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Southwest  Flood  Damage  Rehabilitation
Project, and (ii) a proposal for a change in scope, implementation arrangements, reallocation of
loan  proceeds,  and  reemployment  of  loan  savings  from  ongoing  projects  in  Bangladesh  for
rehabilitation of flood damage.

II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
During  late  September  and  early  October  2000  southwest  Bangladesh,  an  area
customarily  not  flood-prone,  experienced  severe  flooding.  The  rapidity  and  magnitude  of
floodwaters affected an area quite unprepared for a disaster of these nature and caused widespread
damage to infrastructure, agriculture, community facilities, and personal property. The Government
requested emergency assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the rehabilitation
of flood-damaged facilities. ADB responded promptly by fielding the Appraisal Mission during 30
October-16  November.1  The  objectives  of  the  Mission  were  to  (i)  assess,  together  with  the
agencies  concerned,  the  extent  of  flood  damage  and  rehabilitation  requirements  in  various
sectors;  (ii)  determine  what  resources  could  be  made  available  from  ongoing  projects;  (iii)
prepare a flood damage rehabilitation project to finance urgent rehabilitation requirements; and
(iv)  explore  the  possibility  of  establishing  a  community  needs-based  social  fund  that  could  be
used to meet postdisaster rehabilitation requirements.

3.
The Mission met with officials of ministries and agencies concerned, representatives of
external  financing  agencies,  and  national  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs).  Bangladesh
Resident  Mission  staff  participated  in  a  multiagency  mission  that  included  various  United
Nations  agencies,  and  bilateral  and  multilateral  financing  agencies.  The  Mission  visited  the
affected  areas  to  initiate  a  needs  assessment  survey  and  hold  field  discussions  with  affected
persons,  local  governments,  and  NGOs.  In  preparing  the  Project,  the  Mission  drew  upon  the
findings of the various assessment teams, NGO reports, Government estimates, and consultant
assessments to develop a picture of the extent of damage and the rehabilitation requirements.
The Mission established the need for a new loan that together with savings from four ongoing
projects  would  meet  the  immediate  needs  for  rehabilitation  in  five  sectors,  as  well  as  provide
funds  for  socioeconomic  rehabilitation  through  a  fund  established  in  a  leading  NGO.  The
Mission’s findings were presented in an aide memoire that was confirmed by the Government
during a wrap-up meeting held on 15 November 2000. A summary of ADB’s assistance package
(the Project and loan savings) for flood damage rehabilitation is presented in Appendix 1.

By  early  October,  the  damage  in  the  southwest  area  was  estimated  at:  six  districts

7.
Unlike many parts of Bangladesh, the southwest region is generally not flood-prone as
75  percent  of  the  land  is  high  and  medium  high.  The  last  flood  that  local  residents  can  recall
was over 60 years ago. Hence, the rapidity and magnitude of floodwaters affected an area quite
unprepared for such a disaster. Over the years, the buildup of infrastructure (particularly east-
west  feeder  roads),  extensive  construction  of  shrimp-farm  embankments,  dilapidation  of
drainage  facilities  and  water  control  structures,  siltation  in  rivers  and  canals  (many  of  which
began  dying  several  years  ago),  and  lack  of  attention  to  drainage  patterns  has  created  a

 3

situation  that  has  significantly  slowed  the  recession  of  floodwaters.  The  waters  continued  to
cover most areas even six weeks after the first onrush.

8.
The  populations  affected  by  the  waters  have  little  in  the  way  of  coping  strategies,
particularly  the  many  who  have  lost  their  entire  possessions  and  currently  face  a  tenuous
existence in the relief camps. Those who managed to salvage a few possessions have had to
resort to distress sales, particularly of livestock for which fodder and facilities were not available,
to generate income. The evident immediate needs are for food, shelter, clothing, medicine, and
sanitation  facilities.  In  the  medium  term,  agricultural  rehabilitation  will  be  a  priority  —  crops
(much  of  the aman  standing  crop  has  been  destroyed,  and  the  planting  of  winter boro  will  be
delayed),  livestock,  fisheries  (particularly  hatcheries),  agroforestry,  and  homestead  gardens.
Reconstruction  of  village  facilities  and  housing  —  most  houses  in  the  area  were  of  sun-dried
mud that disintegrated in the flooding — will also be a priority, and financial resources in grants
and microcredit will be needed.

B.

Impact of the 2000 Floods

1.

Macroeconomic Outlook

9.
In the aftermath of the 1998 floods, the growth rate of gross domestic product (GDP) in
FY1999  slowed  due  to  (i)  disruptions  of  the  production  and  transportation  systems  of  the
manufacturing  sector  (including  the  export  sector);  (ii)  crop  damage  and  shortage  of  food
supplies; (iii) increased import of foodgrains; (iv) increased Government spending, fiscal deficits,
and  borrowing  from  the  banking  system  to  recoup  the  losses;  and  (v)  increased  inflation.  As
shown in Table 2, manufacturing growth in FY1999 dropped by almost half to 4.9 percent from
the preflood level of 8.3 percent in FY1998. Export growth decreased from 16.8 percent to 2.9
percent  between  FY1998  and  FY1999,  while  import  growth  increased  from  5.1  percent  to  6.6
percent, thereby raising the current account deficit from 1.1 percent of GDP to 1.4 percent. At
the same time, foreign exchange reserves declined from $1.8 billion to $1.5 billion, equivalent to
only  2.3  months  of  imports.  With  greater  need  for  rehabilitation,  Government  spending  and,
hence, the fiscal deficit increased from 13.3 and 4.1 percent of GDP in FY1998 to 13.8 and 4.8
percent of GDP, in FY1999. The Government financed the deficit by borrowing from the banking
system;  this  resulted  in  increases  in  money  supply  and  inflation  from  10.2  and  7  percent  in
FY1998 to 12.8 and 9 percent, in FY1999. Fortunately, the bumper harvest of boro (winter) rice
contributed  significantly  to  avoid  an  economic  downturn.  Agriculture  growth  increased  to  4.8
percent in FY1999 compared with the preflood level of 3.2 percent.  The dampening effect of the
1998 floods on overall economic growth was thus milder than it would have been, with a slight
decline to 4.9 percent in FY1999 as against the preflood level of 5.2 percent in FY1998.

10.
During  FY2000,  prior  to  the  recent  flooding  in  the  southwestern  region  of  the  country,
overall  economic  performance  was  satisfactory  except  for  poor  fiscal  performance.  Economic
growth  increased  to  5.5  percent  in  FY2000,  mainly  because  of  the  acceleration  of  agricultural
growth to 6.4 percent in the same year.  Such acceleration also contributed to reducing inflation
to  3.8  percent  in  FY2000.  Manufacturing  growth  increased  slightly  to  5.6  percent  in  FY2000,
whereas  service  sector  growth  remained  at  around  6  percent.  Export  growth  increased  to  9
percent in FY2000, while import growth increased slightly to 6.8 percent. However, due to high
remittance  growth  of  about  14  percent  in  FY2000,  the  current  account  deficit  dropped  to  1
percent of GDP. Foreign exchange reserves remained at a low level of $1.5 billion—equivalent
to only 2.3 months of import. On the fiscal side, the fiscal deficit increased to 6.1 percent of GDP
in FY2000 due to high Government spending of 15.5 percent of GDP and low revenue collection
of  8.9  percent  of  GDP.  With  greater  bank  borrowing  to  finance  the  deficit,  money  supply

Unlike  the  nationwide  1998  floods,  the  recent  flooding  was  concentrated  in  the

the forthcoming election. Coupled with the recent increase in oil prices, the resulting inflation in
FY2001 is expected to be higher than that in FY2000.

2.

Roads and Rural Infrastructure

12.
The floods inundated about 60 percent of the land area in seven southwestern districts.
Damage  to  the  road  network  was  extensive.  Initially,  various  road  links  were  under  water  and
the  pavement  structures  became  weaker  as  the  duration  of  inundation  increased.  During  this
time,  the  roads  were  still  traversed  by  trucks  and  buses.  Although  the  movement  of  vehicles
contributed significantly to the premature deterioration of pavement surfaces, the need to move
people and supplies could not be denied. The next phase of road damage occurred when the
floodwaters  started  to  recede.  As  the  water  rushed  to  find  convenient  outlets,  embankments
were scoured, abutments washed away, and many bridges and culverts damaged or destroyed.
With road transport to the southwest districts of the country completely cut off, relief efforts used

 5

other transport means or longer land routes. In areas most affected by the floods, the social and
economic  cost  was  high,  and  complete  recovery  will  require  repair  or  rehabilitation  of  the
infrastructure,  including  roads,  bridges,  and  culverts  damaged  by  the  floods.  Damage  is
significant for about 600 kilometers (km) of roads, 1,213 km of embankment, and 800 bridges
and  culverts.  In  the  reconstruction  effort,  it  will  be  necessary  not  only  to  rehabilitate  damaged
infrastructure, but also construct some bridges and culverts at places cut or breached to enable
drainage of floodwaters.

3.

Water Management and Drainage Facilities

13.
The  recent  floods  damaged  the  water  management  and  drainage  facilities  in  the
southwest  region.  This  infrastructure  was  originally  designed  to  cope  with  normal  floods,  but
with  the  recent  major  flood,  substantial  parts  of  these  facilities  became  overloaded  and  broke
down.  The  problem  was  aggravated  because  adequate  routine  maintenance  had  not  been
provided in previous years to repair damage caused by small floods. Based on an assessment
for the Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB), over $46.0 million would be needed to
rehabilitate  BWDB  infrastructure,  including  246  km  of  flood  control  embankments,  865  km  of
drainage canals, 437 water control structures (minor bridges and culverts), river bank protection
work, and other infrastructure.

4.

Foodgrains, Shrimp Farms, and Fishponds

14.
The Ministry of Food estimated the country’s total rice and wheat production to be 24.31
million  tons  (t)  in  FY2000,  0.6  million  t  below  the  FY2000  level.  The  original  area  planted  to
aman rice was 5.9 million hectares (ha). With the loss of 0.15 million ha of the aman area from
recent  flood,  5.75  million  ha  remains.  Given  the  estimated  aman  yield  of  1.73/ha,  the  total
quantity  of  aman  produced  would  be  9.9  million  t  while  the  total  quantity  lost  would  be  0.26
million t. The estimated production of aus and boro rice, as well as wheat of 1.55, 11.02, and
1.84 million t, respectively, the total foodgrain production for FY2001 would be 24.31 million t.
After deducting 10 percent for seeds, feed, wastage, and damage, and including 1.2 million t of
maize, total foodgrain production would be 22.96 million t. This would approximately balance the
overall  foodgrain  requirement  of  21.68  million  t  for  131  million  people  on  an  average
requirement  basis  (454  gm/capita/day).  Food  shortage  does  not  appear  to  be  a  problem,  the
key issues are the delivery of adequate food resources and the need to accelerate drainage and
agricultural rehabilitation to ensure that the expected production for 2001 is achieved.

At  the  affected  area  level,  the  unprecedented  flood  that  started  in  the  third  week  of
15.
September engulfed six southwest districts, resulting in a complete loss of about 150,000 ha of
standing crops. The main crops — transplanted aman and horticulture — were submerged and
farmers had no means of protecting the seeds of rabi crops, mainly boro paddy, vegetables, and
spices.  The  affected  area  is  the  early  vegetable-producing  region  of  the  country.  When  the
floods  struck,  most  of  the  vegetable  crops  (eggplant,  country  beans,  cauliflower,  cabbage,
tomatoes,  gourd)  were  at  various  stages  of  harvesting.  The  total  production  loss  is  about
420,000  tons  of  rice  and  vegetables  worth  $83.64  million.  About  130,000  hectares  of  aman
paddy and 24,000 ha of summer vegetables were completely damaged. Among the horticultural
crops,  80-90  percent  of  papaya  plantations  and  70-80  percent  of  jackfruit  trees  (highly
susceptible to waterlogging) were destroyed. Homestead gardens, among the major sources of
income  for  resource-poor  farm  families  headed  primarily  by  women,  were  also  extensively
devastated.  Farmers  in  flooded  areas  keep  seeds  for  the  next  cropping  season.  With  over  90
percent  of  seeds  being  farmer-saved,  the  sudden  flooding  destroyed  most  of  the  seedstocks.
With the five seed multiplication farms in the area heavily damaged, a seed crisis is foreseen.

 6

The seed multiplication farms need to be rehabilitated urgently to supply seeds to the affected
farms  for  the  coming  cropping  season.  Livestock  losses  were  also  substantial,  primarily  with
distress  sales  to  generate  income,  lack  of  fodder  (scarcity  of  rice  straw),  and  rapidly
deteriorating health of the animals. The loss of livestock represents not only a major asset loss,
but  also  constrains  agricultural  rehabilitation  as  the  animals  provide  the  draught  power  for  the
fields. The flood has affected not only the landowners who have lost their crops, but also many
of the functionally landless who are dependent on agricultural employment during the harvesting
season.

16.
Information  from  satellite  images  indicates  that  approximately  8,600  ha  (67  percent)  of
the shrimp-farm area was lost due to the recent flood. However, as the floods came at the end
of the harvesting season, the losses were not as high as anticipated with about 1,200 t valued at
about $5.0 million. About 4,300 t of whitefish worth over $2.6 million were also washed away.
Rehabilitation of shrimp-farm and fishpond infrastructure is estimated at over $9.0 million.

5.

Social Infrastructure

17.
The  major  health  problems  caused  by  the  2000  floods  have  been  (i)  communicable
diseases such as diarrhea, dysentery, acute respiratory infections, and skin diseases; (ii) those
related  to  water  contamination  and  poor  sanitation.  In  the  34  affected  upazilas,  66  health
centers were damaged.  During the floods, 524 treatment and relief centers were set up; 41,391
cases  of  diarrhea  were  treated,  8,756  cases  of  acute  respiratory  infection,  and  83,827  others.
By late October, fewer than 50 deaths had been reported, a remarkably low figure, attributable
to timely emergency assistance.

18.
The  major  needs  in  the  health  sector  were  (i)  rehabilitation  of  damaged  health  care
facilities;  (ii)  medicines  and  oral  rehydration  supplements,  and  (iii)  health  education  materials.
Sanitation emerged as a major issue in the temporary relief shelters, particularly for women who
had little or no privacy and consequently suffered physiological problems.

19.
Being  largely  mud  structures,  over  500  primary  schools  were  extensively  damaged  by
the  floods.  Some  350  secondary  schools  were  also  affected,  but  not  necessarily  structurally.
The resources provided by ADB’s ongoing Secondary Education Sector Project2 for repair and
reconstruction  of  secondary  schools  damaged  by  the  1998  flood  will  also  be  used  to  cover
damage  from  the  2000  flood.  The  World  Bank-financed  Primary  Education  Development
Program provides for the construction of new schools, and reconstruction and rehabilitation of
damaged primary schools.

E.

Lessons Learned

ADB has provided emergency assistance to Bangladesh through seven loans,3 as well
26.
as through the reallocation of loan savings. Two projects have been postevaluated.4 A review of
the  project  performance  audit  reports,  and  organizational  experience  with  rehabilitation
assistance  indicates  the  following  lessons:  (i)  ADB  must  prepare  rehabilitation  projects  as
quickly as possible; (ii) projects should be limited to restoring facilities to substantially preflood
levels; (iii) implementation periods should be short and, to the extent possible, completed in one
or two construction seasons; (iv) as project implementation places a heavy burden on EA staff,
a  higher  degree  of  consulting  support  and  ADB  supervision  is  needed  during  implementation,
(v)  efforts  should  be  made  to  ensure  that  ADB’s  rapid  response  to  disasters  is  matched  by
equally  quick  action  on  the  part  of  the  Government;  (vi)  beneficiary  participation  in  project
preparation and implementation must be increased, especially for the maintenance of facilities;
(vii) environment and social aspects should be considered in project design; (viii) arrangements
for disbursement should give EAs quick and simple access to funds; (ix) objectives and scope
need  to  be  carefully  defined;  (x)  criteria  for  subproject  selection  should  permit  simple
prioritization  of  subprojects,  and  short  implementation  periods;  and  (xi)  the  presence  of  a
steering  committee  chaired  by  senior  civil  servants  has  the  positive  effect  of  bringing  together
project  directors  of  the  many  project  components,  as  well  as  expediting  decision-making
processes and activities to be implemented.

F.

ADB’s Country Strategy

30.
Consistent  with  the  Government’s  medium-term  development  strategy,  ADB’s  country
operational  strategy  for  Bangladesh  identifies  poverty  reduction  as  its  overall  strategic
objective.6  This  will  be  achieved  by  targeting  four  priority  areas:  promotion  of  faster  private
sector-led  economic  growth,  creation  of  better  development  opportunities  for  the  poor  in  rural
and  urban  areas,  human  development,  and  environmental  protection.  The  poverty  reduction
objective  emphasized  in  the  strategy  was  amplified  in  the  recently  signed  Partnership
Agreement on Poverty Reduction between ADB and the Government.7 The agreement sets long
and  medium-term  goals  based  on  the  Government’s  vision  and  plans  for  poverty  reduction  —
both  the  income  and  nonincome  aspects.  It  also  guides  ADB’s  medium-term  operations  to
support the Government’s medium-term priorities through pro-poor growth, social development,
and  good  governance.  To  make  growth  more  pro-poor,  the  strategy  is  to  adopt  an  area
approach to focus assistance on areas with high concentrations of poverty.

31.
The  Project  is  consistent  with  the  country  operational  strategy  and  the  Partnership
Agreement in that it will rehabilitate key physical and social infrastructure essential to restoring
normal levels of economic and social activities. This will, in turn, improve the poverty situation
aggravated  by  the  flood  damage.  The  Project  will  also  contribute  to  clearing  up  the
environmental  damage  caused  by  the  floods.  The  incidence  of  poverty  in  most  of  the  flood-
affected  districts  in  the  region  varies  between  40-50  percent  compared  with  the  national
average  of  44.7  percent.  One  of  those  districts,  Kushtia,  has  a  poverty  incidence  of  over  50
percent. However, in the postflood situation, poverty has reached alarming proportions owing to
massive  income  erosion,  complete  loss  of  physical  assets,  and  debt  accumulation.  Timely
assistance  is  critical  to  ensuring  that  the  current  poverty  profile  does  not  become  a  long-term
feature in southwest Bangladesh.

Environmental and Social Measures

1.

Environment

The  Project  has  been  classified  as  environmental  category  B:  and  is  not  likely  to  have
83.
any  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts.  Civil  works  will  involve  rehabilitation  or
reconstruction  of  flood-damaged  infrastructure.  Reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of  roads  and
railways  will  follow  existing  alignments  and  will  avoid  acquisition  of  land  or  resettlement.  All
subprojects will follow environmental safeguards and technical design specifications established
for  ongoing  ADB  projects,  which  have  already  been  subjected  to  ADB’s  environmental
assessment  procedures.  During  the  flood,  the  cross  drains  of  the  highways  were  found
inadequate and in a number of sections that used to be natural channels for runoff, residents cut
the highway to allow free passage of floodwaters. Both RHD and LGED have realized the need
to  increase  the  number  of  cross  drains  and  may  retain  the  breached  sections  as  permanent
channels  for  surface  runoff.  In  instances  were  the  highway  served  as  a  bund  preventing  the
inland  flow  of  saline  water,  the  channels  can  be  provided  with  sluice  gates  to  control  the
direction of water flow. Although any application of the proposed Project for construction outside
of the existing right of way of the damaged infrastructure is not foreseen, in instances that the
flood  may  have  destroyed  the  integrity  of  the  existing  alignment  and  repair  along  existing
alignment may pose risk to public safety, a new alignment may have to be considered. In that
situation,  the  EA  concerned  will  prepare  an  IEE  for  submission  to  ADB  for  approval  on  a  no-
objection  basis  prior  to  starting  construction.  The  Project  will  have  positive  environmental
benefits by limiting land erosion and failure of embankments along damaged infrastructure and

 22

by  reducing  health  risks  by  rehabilitating  damaged  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  and
cleaning drainage systems.

2.

Social Dimensions

84.
A  participatory  rapid  appraisal  was  conducted  to  assess  the  socioeconomic  impacts  of
floods. A social and poverty assessment is in Appendix 10. As a first step to designing the SRF,
need assessments were conducted in six affected districts to gather information about the need
and  demand  of  flood  victims.  The  assessments  identified  the  magnitude  of  socioeconomic
impacts  people  face;  community  efforts  to  address  flood  victim  needs;  presence  and  role  of
Government, NGOs, and community-based organizations; the constraints the community faces
as a result of the disaster; and measures to mitigate those impacts and address the needs of
affected persons.

85.
Approximately 500,000 houses were affected by floods. About 2 million-3 million people
in the flooded areas were exposed to the elements. About 80-90 percent of mud houses in the
areas  did  not  survive  the  floods  and  will  need  to  be  reconstructed.  Damage  to  crops,
infrastructure and homestead gardens was substantial.  The standing aman rice (harvest due in
November)  and  summer  vegetable  and  fruit  crops  were  seriously  affected  by  floods.  A  large
number of tubewells were inundated and will need to be rehabilitated. Persistent waterlogging
problems exist in many areas creating inhuman living conditions and spreading diseases. The
clean  water  supply  situation  is  insufficient  and  latrines  are  scarce.  A  major  concern  is  the
situation  after  the  recession  of  floodwaters  when  the  risk  of  epidemics,  particularly  diarrheal
diseases and skin diseases will be high.  Thus, social issues, such as provision of a safety net
for affected people, particularly the poor and vulnerable groups, have emerged as major issues.
Based  on  community  consultations,  the  major  demands  are:  (i)  drainage  rehabilitation;  (ii)
housing; (iii) working capital for on- and off-farm income-generating activities; (iv) employment;
and  (v)  rehabilitation  of  rural  and  urban  basic  infrastructure  facilities  such  as  roads,  schools,
tubewells, community health centers, and irrigation facilities.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Benefits

86.
The  benefits  of  the  emergency  loan  will  be  evident  in  the  speedy  rehabilitation  of
infrastructure  and  facilities  in  the  affected  areas.  By  rehabilitating  public  and  community
infrastructure, the Project will help restore social and economic activities disrupted by the flood.
The Project will reduce flooding and waterlogging of agricultural land, benefiting residents and
farmers in low-lying flood-prone areas.  Improved community water and sanitation facilities will
help  reduce  risk  of  health-related  problems  and  improve  quality  of  life.  Aside  from  relieving
human  and  societal  distress,  the  Project  will  have  economic  benefits,  which  are  likely  to  be
substantial  although  not  fully  quantifiable.  The  civil  works  under  the  rural  road  rehabilitation
component  alone  are  expected  to  provide  about  262,500  person-days  employment  to  local
skilled  and  unskilled  labor.  The  Project  will  help  bring  the  farmlands  in  six  districts  back  to
productivity,  and  allow  people  to  regain  employment  and  to  generate  incomes  of  their  own
instead  of  relying  on  Government  emergency  assistance.  Flood  disasters  affect  the  poor
disproportionately  in  terms  of  health,  housing,  employment,  livelihood,  and  food  security.
Rehabilitation of vital infrastructure will allow resumption of communication links and economic
activity  disrupted  by  flood  damage.  The  Project  will  involve  the  repair  and  rehabilitation  of
existing roads and bridges; irrigation canals; and urban and community infrastructure, such as

 23

water supply, drainage, sewage collection and disposal, and health and education facilities that
were damaged by the floods.

B.

Risks

87.
The risk of procedural delays in obtaining various Government approvals that may slow
implementation has been offset by the Government’s agreement to use simplified procedures.
The selection of EAs with considerable experience in implementing ADB-assisted projects and
with  familiarity  with  ADB  procedures,  implementation  by  established  project  implementation
units, and use of existing or directly selected consultants minimizes the likelihood of delay at the
EA level. The availability of counterpart funding has not been a problem to date for ADB projects
in Bangladesh. The risk of selecting unnecessary subprojects and of governance-related issues
is addressed by the detailed selection criteria, strong consultant support, and the provisions of
ADB’s  anticorruption  policy,  which  have  been  specifically  brought  to  the  attention  of  the
Government and all EAs.

C.

Impact on Poverty

88.
The  project  area  is  characterized  by  high  levels  of  poverty.  The  national  statistics  in
Table 5 tend to hide the incidence of poverty across upazilas and the impact of the 2000 floods
in  an  area  previously  thought  to  have  a  moderate  level  of  food  security,  such  as  in  Satkhira.
Currently,  in  the  affected  areas,  poverty  is  as  high  as  80-90  percent  with  the  loss  of  physical
assets  and  income-generating  opportunities  caused  by  the  flood.  The  prevalence  of  poverty
among  landless  households  and  households  headed  by  women  is  particularly  high.  The
estimated  numbers  within  vulnerable  groups  (such  as  children  under  5  years  age,  pregnant
mothers,  and  elderly  people)  among  the  total  population  is  approximately  22  percent.  A  rapid
poverty assessment was conducted in the project area.  Most of the people living in the project
area  are  directly  or  indirectly  involved  in  agricultural  production.  About  27  percent  are  literate.
The  proportion  of  literacy  among  males  (67  percent)  is  more  than  double  the  literacy  among
females (33 percent).  In the project area, female labor is engaged in the traditional household
work, agriculture, fishing, petty trade, and some low-level nonfarm jobs. The lower the status of
the  family  (landless  and  marginal),  the  higher  the  percentage  of  women  involved  in  activities
other  than  household  work.  The  poverty  reduction  needs  addressed  through  the  Project  will
involve  urgent  drainage  works  to  allow  faster  recession  of  water  and  enable  agricultural
activities  to  resume  microcredit  for  village  reconstruction  and  livelihood  restoration,  and
rehabilitation of infrastructure to restore access.

NATIONAL, REGIONAL, AND TYPE-A FEEDER ROADS

A.

Damage and Impact

1.
The  floods  that  started  on  17  September  2000  inundated  about  60  percent  of  the  land
area in southwest Bangladesh, principally in seven districts. Damage to the road network was
extensive.  Initially,  various  road  links  were  under  water  and  the  pavement  structures  became
weaker as the duration of inundation increased. During this time, the roads were still traversed
by  trucks  and  buses.  The  movement  of  vehicles  contributed  significantly  to  the  destruction  of
pavement  surfaces,  but  the  need  to  move  people  and  supplies  around  the  country  was
necessary.  The  next  phase  of  road  damage  occurred  when  the  floodwaters  started  to  recede
and  as  the  water  rushed  to  find  convenient  outlets,  embankments  were  scoured,  abutments
washed  away,  and  many  bridges  and  culverts  were  damaged  or  disappeared.  With  road
transport to the southwest districts of the country completely cut off, relief efforts were met by
other transport means or through longer land routes. In areas most affected by the floods, the
social and economic cost was high, and complete recovery will require repair or rehabilitation of
the infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and culverts, damaged by the floods.

2.
About  600  kilometers  (km)  of  roads  were  submerged,  and  damage  was  sustained  to
1,213 km of embankment, and 800 bridges and culverts. The total estimated cost of the damage
at  that  time  was  Tk2,302  million  ($42.5  million).  Consultants  will  be  engaged  to  refine  these
estimates using a detailed assessment and to supervise construction.

Scope

3.
Under Part A of the Project, flood-damaged national, regional, and feeder type-A roads
will be rehabilitated, essentially to their condition before the flood within eight districts of Khulna
zone under the Roads and Highways Department (RHD).

4.
This  component  of  the  Project  will  cover  all  repair  and  reconstruction  necessary  to
restore the basic road transport network to full serviceability conditions prior to the 2000 flood.
The  project  consultants  will  conduct  a  detailed  damage  assessment  that  will  identify  priorities
and  estimate  the  rehabilitation  cost.  Although  the  priorities  will  be  followed  to  prepare
subprojects,  exceptions  can  be  made  in  line  with  the  criteria  for  subprojects  shown  in  para.  5
and in consultation with the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Repairs will vary from minor repair
of an existing facility to the rehabilitation and reconstruction of culverts or bridges. Repair works
will be carried out to restore the facility to the preflood level or to a marginally higher standard as
considered  cost  effective,  and  where  appropriate  will  include  flood  protection  measures  to
minimize damage from future floods.

Damage and Impact

1.
Bangladesh  experienced  an  abnormal  late  monsoon  flood  in  2000  in  the  southwest

bridges  and  culverts,  at  many  locations  the  road  pavement  had  to  be  cut  open  to  allow  faster

Project.  PKSF  was  established  in  May  1990  under  the  Companies  Act  of  1913  as  an
autonomous,  nonprofit  organization  charged  with  “helping  the  poor,  the  landless,  and  the
assetless  in  order  to  enable  them  to  gain  access  to  resources  for  their  productive  self-

income-generating  activities  within  their  local  areas  in  Bangladesh.  Although  many  of  these
NGOs were competently managed, they generally suffered from a perennial shortage of funds.
PKSF was thus formed to finance such NGOs. In support of this objective, PKSF received an
initial grant of Tk32.0 million from the Government, and it has subsequently received additional
grants from the Government for a total of Tk750.0 million.  At the end of 1999, the total equity of
PKSF was Tk5,920.0 million.  While PKSF functions as an autonomous publicly funded body, it
falls under the overall supervision of the Ministry of Finance.  PKSF is the apex organization for

Development  Association,  as  well  as  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Participatory
Livestock Development Project in 1997.

for  the  creation  of  productive  self-employment  opportunities.  This  is  achieved  by  (i)  providing

SOCIAL AND POVERTY ASSESSMENT

A.

Background

1.
The Project will restore and rehabilitate public and community infrastructure facilities in
six  districts  of  southwest  Bangladesh  that  were  damaged  by  the  recent  flood,  and  restore
socioeconomic conditions of flood victims by providing of microcredit.  The project area is mostly
poor  and  poverty  levels  are  very  high.  The  Project  will  enable  the  restoration  of  social  and
economic  activities  of  these  six  districts,  and  create  opportunities  for  employment  or  income-
generation, particularly for poor men and women through labor-intensive activities.

B.

The Project Area

2.
The  project  area  is  located  in  the  southwestern  region  of  Bangladesh,  and  comprises
seven  districts:  Chuadanga,  Jessore,  Jhenidah,  Kusthia,  Magura,  Meherpur,  and  Satkhira.  It
covers  about  11,103  square  kilometers  (km2)  of  mixed  use  land,  and  has  a  population  of
approximately 8 million. The total affected area is 3,239 km2 with population of 2 million-3 million
people. The affected areas have not experienced flooding for the last 60 years. Poor rural and
urban infrastructures and poor living conditions (i.e., mud houses) characterize the area.

3.
Due  to  the  heavy  rainfall  in  West  Bengal  State,  water  flows  from  the  upper  catchment
areas of India, and heavy rainfall in southwestern Bangladesh, the project area was flooded to
an average depth of 1.8 to 3.0 meters within a few days. About 80-90 percent of mud houses in
the area were damaged. In Satkhira, at least 500,000 people were rendered homeless as the
unprecedented  floods  destroyed  some  68,000  houses  completely  and  some  47,000  houses
partially. Over 600,000 people in this district alone took shelter in schools, colleges, madrasahs,
and other public places.

4.
Most  of  social  infrastructure  facilities  such  as  schools  and  health  centers  have  not
survived the floods and will need to be reconstructed. A large number of tube wells have been
inundated  and  most  will  likely  need  to  be  resunk.  Damage  to  crops  and  infrastructure  was
substantial. The standing aman rice (harvest due in November) and summer vegetable and fruit
crops  were  seriously  affected  by  the  flood.  The  damage  to  rural  roads  and  embankments  is
substantial. While the damage to national and regional highways is less severe, resources will
have to be spent on reconstructing culverts and bridges, particularly at places where the roads
had to be cut or were breached by floodwaters.

nongovernment  agencies  (NGO)  representatives,  farmers,  shop  owners,  landowners,  and
people who were most adversely affected by the floods in the project area. Consultations and a
series  of  meetings  were  conducted  with  key  stakeholders  including  international  and  national
NGOs, government officials, and assistance agencies working in the field.

1.

National Levels

7.
Nearly  80  percent  of  Bangladesh’s  population  of  130  million  people  live  in  rural  areas.
The  most  recent  countrywide  evidence  on  the  poverty  status1  shows  that  36  percent  of

households were reported as being completely landless.

8.
While poverty is best measured by comparing per capita consumption to a poverty line,
other dimensions of well-being are not captured by such measures.  Women in Bangladesh lack
access  to  health  and  education,  and  have  a  lower  life  expectancy  than  men  at  birth.  Rural
households  headed  by  women  had  a  higher  probability  of  being  among  the  very  poor  than
households  headed  by  men  (45  percent  compared  with  39  percent).  The  headcount  ratios  for
poor  households  were  virtually  identical  for  households  headed  by  females  and  males.
Because households headed by females had smaller families and per capita consumption data
was used as a welfare indicator, poverty among smaller families was underestimated compared
with  larger  families,  and  in  households  headed  by  women3.  If  the  distribution  of  consumption
within households favors men, poverty among women is likely to be higher still.

In  Bangladesh,  the  burden  of  poverty  falls  disproportionately  on  women.  The  most
9.
disadvantaged  women  are  those  heading  or  managing  households,  about  15  percent  of  all
households.  On average, households headed by females earn only 55 percent of the earnings
of the national average households.  About 96 percent of these households are living below the
poverty  line,  while  33  percent  are  living  below  the  lower  poverty  line  and  thus  experience
chronic of food shortages.

Poor  Bangladeshis  have  little  access  to  resources.  In  rural  areas,  poor  people,

microcredit programs of NGOs and other noninstitutional lending sources. The Grameen Bank
and some NGO credit programs, such as Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation (PKSF), Bangladesh
Rural Advancement Committee (BRAC), and Proshika provide loans to poor people and target

2.

Poverty in Project Area

11.
Prior to the floods, the level of poverty in the southwest region was lower than in other
parts  of  Bangladesh.  With  massive  income  erosion  and  complete  loss  of  physical  assets,  the
affected areas now face abject poverty. The prevalence of poverty among landless households
and  households  headed  by  women  is  particularly  high.  The  estimated  number  of  vulnerable
groups (such as children under 5 years age, pregnant mothers, and elderly people) among the
total population is approximately 22 percent.

12.
A rapid poverty assessment was conducted in the project area during appraisal. Most of
the people of the project area are involved in agricultural production either directly or indirectly.
About 27  percent of  the  population  in the region are literate. The proportion of literacy among
males (67 percent) is more than double the literacy among females (33 percent). In the project
area, women’s labor is engaged in traditional household works: agriculture, fishing, petty trade,
and some low-level nonfarm jobs. The lower the status of the families (landless and marginal),
the higher the percentage of women involved in activities other than household works.

13.
Persistent  waterlogging  problems  exist  in  many  areas,  creating  inhuman  living
conditions, spread of diseases, and lack of employment opportunities. The clean water supply
situation  is  insufficient  and  latrines  are  scarce.  A  major  concern  is  the  situation  after  the
recession  of  floodwaters  when  the  risk  of  epidemics,  particularly  diarrhea  as  well  as  skin
diseases, will be high.  Thus, social issues, such as provision of a safety net for affected people,
particularly the poor and vulnerable groups, have emerged as major issues.

D.

Project Beneficiaries

14.
Through  the  rehabilitation  of  public  and  community  infrastructure,  the  Project  will  help
restore  social  and  economic  activities  disrupted  by  the  flood.  The  Project  will  reduce  flooding
and waterlogging of agricultural land, benefiting residents and farmers in low-lying flood-prone
areas.  Improved  water  and  sanitation  facilities  will  help  reduce  risk  of  health-related  problems
and  improved  quality  of  life.  Aside  from  relieving  human  and  societal  distress,  the  Project  will
have economic benefits that are likely to be substantial although perhaps not quantifiable. The
civil works under the Project are expected to provide employment of about 262,500 person-days
to local skilled and unskilled labor. The Project will help bring the farmlands and in six districts
back  to  productivity  and  allow  people  to  regain  employment  and  to  generate  incomes  of  their
own instead of relying on government emergency assistance. Table A10 provides an indicative
number of beneficiaries of the Project.

15.
The  project  component  with  the  greatest  potential  to  impact  on  existing  poverty
conditions  within  the  project  area  is  the  Socioeconomic  Rehabilitation  Fund  (SRF)  to  be
implemented  in  six  districts.  Based  on  the  poverty  assessment,  approximately  45  percent  of
people who live in these districts are living below the official poverty level.

E.

Needs and Demands for Infrastructure Development

Approximately  80-90  percent  of  houses  in  these  areas  are  made  from  mud,  and  the
16.
population  in  the  flooded  areas  appears  to  be  most  exposed  to  the  elements.  Most  of  those
buildings  did  not  survive  the  floods  and  will  need  to  be  reconstructed.  Damage  to  crops  and
infrastructure was substantial. The standing aman rice (harvest due in November) and summer
vegetable and fruit crops were seriously affected by floods. A large number of tubewells have
been inundated and will need to be rehabilitated. Based on community consultations, the major
demand  were  (i)  drainage  rehabilitation;  (ii)  housing;  (iii)  working  capital  for  on-  and  off-farm,
income-generating  activities;  (iv)  employment;  (v)  rehabilitation  of  rural  and  urban  basic
infrastructure  facilities,  such  as  roads,  schools,  tube  wells,  community  health  centers,  and
irrigation facilities.

F.

Role of NGOs

17.
Bangladesh is internationally known for its innovative NGOs, which have grown rapidly.
In the project area, NGOs play a major role in providing relief programs for flood victims such as

 63

Appendix 10, page 5

temporary shelters, food distribution, health, water supply, and sanitation facilities. Microfinance
programs  such  as  those  provided  by  Bangladesh  Rural  Advancement  Committee  (BRAC),
Association for Social Advancement (ASA), Proshika, Palli Karma Sahayak Foundation (PKSF),
and Grameen Bank are among the best known. In addition to microfinance, NGOs provide skill
training, education, health, family planning, and water supply and sanitation facilities. NGOs are
also  active  in  managing  common  property  resources,  extending  nontraditional  agriculture,  and
initiating  income-generating  activities.  Microfinance  programs  are  effective  in  fighting  poverty.
The superior performance of microfinance NGO services offers possibilities of partnership with
the Government to provide loans for housing, and working capital for on- and off-farm, income-
generating activities for flood victims, particularly the poor and vulnerable groups.

G.

Project Impact on Women

18.
The  various  project  components  will  benefit  women  in  a  number  of  ways.  Bangladeshi
women  have  high  labor  force  participation  rates,  many  earn  their  incomes  from  agricultural
wage  labor,  trading  activities  in  the  home  or  the  markets.  The  Project  will  benefit  women  by
providing  employment  opportunities  for  rehabilitation  of  public  and  community  infrastructure
facilities.  The  provision  of  community  water  and  sanitation  facilities  will  benefit  women  and
children substantially in terms of health and quality of life.

19.
Gender considerations have been built into the design of the Project to ensure equitable
access  to  employment  creation  and  poverty  reduction  opportunities,  as  well  as  to  ensure  that
the  perspective  and  needs  of  the  entire  community  are  reflected  in  the  planning  and
implementation  process,  particularly  in  the  SRF.  Furthermore,  an  important  contribution  of  the
SRF component will be empowerment of women in the project area. The SRF will incorporate
participatory  approaches  involving  civil  society  at  various  stages  of  the  development  process,
from planning to implementation, and monitoring and evaluation. The SRF requires that women
participate in a meaningful way both at decision-making levels and as beneficiaries of the labor
required by the Project. As participants, they will represent their respective communities in the
decision-making  process.  This  makes  them  accountable  to  their  respective  communities,  and
they  will  therefore  become  public  figures.  This  experience  will  help  empower  women,  and
promote their needs in the village.

H.

Impact on Poor Households

Construction activities, which mostly require unskilled labor, will generate direct income-
20.
earning  opportunities  particularly  for  the  poor.  Over  three  years,  the  Project  will  provide
approximately 652,500 person-days of employment, which consist of direct labor in civil works
and production of materials utilized in constructing the works. Poverty targeting will be achieved
at  the  village  level  through  community  selection,  e.g.,  communities  will  be  able  to  identify  the
needy (the very poor) more efficiently than through any objective screening mechanisms.  The
participatory project monitoring and evaluation system to be developed and implemented under
the  SRF  component  will  require  each  district  and  village  to  make  plans,  and  monitor  the
implementation of that plan, for promoting access of the poor to project benefits.

I.

Community Consultation and Participatory Approaches

21.
The communities that will be directly and indirectly benefited by the project components
will  play  a  significant  part  in  the  planning,  implementation,  and  monitoring  of  the  Project.  The
bottom-up  planning  process  will  be  a  major  feature  of  the  SRF.  During  the  social  and  poverty

 64

Appendix 10, page 6

assessment,  discussions  were  held  with  a  number  of  relevant  stakeholders  such  as  union
parishad,  local  NGOs,  communities,  and  particularly  poor  men  and  women.  The  discussions
helped  to  highlight  issues  faced  by  the  communities.    For  instance,  to  reduce  the  health  risk,
communities  must  have  clean  water  and  sanitation  facilities.  Participatory  approaches  will  be
employed in design, implementation, and monitoring of the Project.

J.

Performance Project Monitoring System (PPMS)

22.
The specific objectives of PPMS are to identify key criteria and indicators to be used for
macro-level  monitoring  of  project  inputs,  outputs,  and  impacts.  The  PPMS  will  enable  the
Executing  Agency  and  ADB  to  determine  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  project
implementation,  to  identify  constraints,  and  to  compare  performance  and  impact  across  six
districts.  The  PPMS  will  be  established  to  assess  the  Project’s  progress  and  implementation
and to measure the impact and outcomes of the Project.  The information obtained will be used
directly to improve development planning and implementation by adjusting delivery mechanisms
and identifying more appropriate strategies.
